awd_titl_txt: On the Impacts of Cloud Radiative Heating on General Circulation and Extreme Events
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will train two graduate students. Both the dynamics-based diagnostic tools developed and data produced in the research project will be made publicly available via online repositories. The funded project will augment previously NSF-funded science outreach programs at Indiana University, including the Jim Holland Research Program which serves under-represented high school students throughout Indiana. The research team will partner with WonderLab, a local museum for Science, Health, and Technology, and local school districts to create and disseminate climate change modules, thereby enhancing Indiana Science Teaching Standards in local K12 classrooms. The results from the research project will be widely disseminated in conferences and peer reviewed publications.

Clouds and the associated precipitations are products of storms of various sizes ranging from a few kilometers to few thousand kilometers.  In extratropics, particularly in winter seasons, clouds and precipitations are produced mainly by cyclones or storms that are few thousand kilometers wide. These large-scale storms are organized by mid-latitude westerly jet stream meandering meridionally along the latitude circle and tend to amplify over the North Pacific and North Atlantic off the east coasts of the two major continents. Latent heating release occurring during the formation of clouds and precipitations is known to play a critical role in the rapid amplification and lengthening of the life cycle of these storms. Besides releasing latent heat, clouds also alter atmospheric radiative heating profile by absorbing thermal energy emission from the surface and atmosphere below that are warmer while radiating heat out at a colder temperature, as well as reflecting more incoming solar energy back to space that causes cooling at the surface. Cloud-induced radiative heating anomalies may have long-lasting effect not only on the development of these storms but also on the westerly jet stream that carries them, as cyclones tend to preferentially amplify or redevelop over certain longitude sections in mid-latitudes, such as the North Pacific and North Atlantic. This research will diagnose how radiative heating anomalies associated with clouds affects the westerly jet and Rossby waves in which cyclones that produce clouds are embedded.  Specifically, the research team will calculate 3D cloud-induced radiative heating rate anomalies in mid-latitudes using observational datasets and modeling output. They will examine the contribution from such anomalies to the low-frequency variability of the westerly jet stream and large-amplitude long-lasting atmospheric circulation anomalies, such as blocking flow.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funded work leveraged a new analytical framework for picking apart the local-to-global drivers of circulation change. Graduate student Samuel J. Smith filled in missing analytical links in published theory and created improved software for performing the analysis. In the process, Smith has become a leading expert on the diagnostic itself, and on the dynamics of the jet streams.

This grant has funded work published in one dissertation, and two papers, with a third paper in the works. The first paper characterizes the impacts of jets and overturning circulation on global transport of moisture. In this paper, we showed that the same analytical framework can be used to understand dry extremes and moist extremes. We also used it to separate changes in precipitation that are due to a shifting jet stream from those that are due to an expanding tropical overturning circulation, and from those that are due simply to thermodynamics. While the thermodynamical-dynamical separation has been done before, our new approach does so exceptionally cleanly, with thermodynamic changes around the globe following theoretical scaling arguments even better previously shown.

The second paper characterizes the impacts of moisture and clouds on the jets, with the surprising result that the role of moisture in an atmosphere model cannot be calculated by subtracting dry-model results from moist-model results. Moist processes interact with dry processes, meaning moist models produce jets that behave differently than in dry models, in part because of changes in dry processes. Specifically, even though the impact of heating due to moisture (mainly released through the condensation) have a stronger impact on jet persistence than previously supposed, but this does not necessarily imply that a moist model will have a longer jet timescale than a dry model.

Another exciting conclusion of work funded by this grant is that certain large scale global weather patterns don’t just have ‘positive’ and ‘negative’ phases, but are better treated as poleward-moving patterns. Doing so provides a more complete dynamical picture of how the modes are sustained (and how the propagate), improves our ability to predict these modes on subseasonal-to-seasonal timescales, and helps us better project how these modes may change with climate.

This grant funded the work of three graduate students. Two of them graduated with Ph.D.s, and the third obtained a STEM job in the private sector. During the performance of this work, the PI and two of the graduate students have reached out to K-12 educators in the state of Indiana to help teachers gain skills and confidence as they use the issue of modern climate change to help students attain state science standards.
